 Vũ Thị Dân sinh năm 1960 (Mã số 010105060006) Chị tham gia mức vay 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn, chị đi làm thợ xây, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs T. Thi Dao was born in 1961. She lives with her husband and her adult son's family. Her husband works as a construction worker, and she has a retirement pension. She is a trustworthy person who is admired by many people. She joined the Fund with a loan of 4,142,000 VND to invest in raising chickens. Her family's average income is about 3,500,000 VND/month. Her group includes: - Mrs. Thu May Thi N., born 1981, participating with a loan of 4,142,000 VND to invest in raising chickens. She works as labor for hire, and her family has an income of about 3,000,000 VND/month. -Mrs. Chuyen Thi N., born 1957, participating with a loan of 4,142,000 VND to invest in raising pigs. Her family's average income is around 2,000,000 VND/month. -Mrs. Dung Thi D., born 1957, participating with a loan of 4,142,000 VND to invest in raising chickens. Her family's average income is about 2,500,000 VND/month. -Mrs. Tac Thi D., born 1963, participating with a loan of 4,142,000 VND to invest in raising pigs and farming flowers. Her family's average income is about 2,000,000 VND/month. -Mrs. Dan Thi V., born in 1960, participating with a loan of 4,142,000 VND to invest in raising pigs. She works as a construction worker; her family's average monthly income is about 3,000,000 VND/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi N., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: invest in raising chickens, pigs

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
“I plan to improve my business through perseverance, courage and hard work,” said Maribel, a village store owner and wife of a carpenter who works abroad. 

Believing in the saying that: "if others can, why can’t I",  Maribel F., is the 40-year-old wife of Chito and mother of their only child John Micheal F., 8 years old and in second grade. Maribel still maintains a small store even though her husband is already working abroad, because she knows that her husband's work there is not for a lifetime.

Maribel requests a loan of $125 (5,000 PHP) to buy additional goods to sell in her store. Her weekly income is about 1,400 PHP, and pays for her child’s education and other basic needs of their family.

loans.use: Buy additional goods to sell in the store

loans.name: Shani

texts.en:
Greatings from Tanzana!  This is 34 year old Shani Y. from Mwanza. She is married with four children, between the ages of 4 and 15 years old. Shani Y. has been operating a café business since 2002. The name of the café is "Mama Lishe". A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long wooden benches. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. She works at her business 12 hours a day, 7 days a week and is assisted by one employee. Shani Y. currently earns about 450USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425USD in order to buy beans, rice and vegetables. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Shani Y. thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy supplies of beans, rice and vegetables

loans.name: Dang Thi Kim Group

texts.vi:
Đặng Thị K. sinh năm 1969 ( mã số 010105060014). Chị đang sống cùng chồng và hai con trai, con chị đang độ tuổi đi học, chồng chị làm nghề lái xe có thu nhập theo ngày. Ngoài công việc đồng áng, chị còn đi chợ bán hoa quả đem lại nguồn thu theo ngày. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 4.000.000 vnđ/ tháng. Với thu nhập theo ngày rất phù hợp với vốn vay trả dần theo tuần nên gia đình chị rất thích và mong muốn được vay vốn thường xuyên. Chị là cụm trưởng cụm vay vốn đồng thời là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay có 7 thành viên. Chu kỳ vốn này chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ bán hoa quả.
 Cùng vay với chị còn có:
 Nguyễn Thị Hạnh sinh năm 1963  ( mã số 010105060015). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ sắt vụn, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ/ tháng.
 Phạm Thị Hoa sinh năm 1966 ( Mã số 010105060016) chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Vũ Thị Bến sinh năm 1976 ( mã số 010105060017). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ sắt vụn. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị Thanh sinh năm 1957 ( mã số 010105060019). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ mua gạo về bán lẻ. Thu nhập bình quân khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ /tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị Hằng sinh năm 1968 ( mã số 010105060020). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư kinh doanh. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị Giới sinh năm 1949 ( mã số 010105060021). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để buôn bán nhỏ ( bán bánh kẹo, nước giải khát,…). Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
texts.en:
Đặng Thị K. was born in 1969. She lives with her husband and two children. Her children go to school and her husband is a driver, earning variable amounts each day. Besides working in the fields, Mrs. K. also sells fruit in the local market. Her family's average income is about 4,000,000 VND (238 USD) per month. Her daily income is well-suited for making weekly payments, so she and her family are very hopeful to be able to borrow at regular intervals. Mrs. K. is both the head of the local borrowers association as well as the leader of this particular group with seven members. In this cycle, she requests 4,142,000 VND (246 USD) to invest in fruit she can sell at the market. Borrowing along with Mrs. K. are: Nguyễn Thị Hạnh, born 1963. She requests 4,142,000 VND (246 USD) to use buying and selling scrap iron. The average income of her family is about 2,500,000 VND (149 USD) per month. Phạm Thị Hoa, born 1966. She requests 4,142,000 VND (246 USD) to invest in raising pigs and chickens. Her family's average monthly income is about 2,000,000 VND (119 USD). Vũ Thị Bến, born 1976. She requests 4,142,000 VND (246 USD) to use buying and selling scrap iron. The average income of her family is about 2,500,000 VND (149 USD) per month. Nguyễn Thị Thanh, born 1957. She requests 4,142,000 VND (246 USD) to buy rice which she can sell at the local market. Her average monthly income is about 2,500,000 VND (149 USD). Nguyễn Thị Hằng, born 1968. She requests 4,142,000 VND (246 USD) to invest in her business. The average income of her family is about 2,500,000 VND (149 USD) per month. Nguyễn Thị Giới, born 1949. She requests 4,142,000 VND (246 USD) to buy candy, drinks, etc., which she can resell. Her family's average income is about 2,000,000 VND (119 USD) per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Selling fruit, rice, snacks, scrap iron.  Raising pigs and chickens.

loans.name: Dang Thi Le Group

texts.vi:
Đặng Thị Lệ sinh năm 1957 ( Mã số 010105060022) hiện đang sống cùng chồng và hai con đã lớn. Gia đình có máy xay sát gạo nên hàng ngày có thu nhập. N.ài ra, chị còn tăng ra sản xuất, chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Chị là người chịu khó và chăm chỉ, tháo vát, năng động, có nhiều nguồn thu( thu nhập từ nông nghiệp, chăn nuôi, công sát gạo,….). Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
 Ngô Thị Hào sinh năm 1966  ( mã số 010105060023). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi lợn, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ/ tháng.
 Phạm Thị Nghi sinh năm 1972 ( Mã số 010105060024) chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hang  sửa chữa xe máy. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 4.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị Đào sinh năm 1979 ( mã số 010105060025). chị vay mức 3.270.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi gà. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Đặng Thị Lự sinh năm 1971 ( mã số 010105060026). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi. Thu nhập bình quân khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ /tháng.
texts.en:
Đặng Thị Lệ, born 1957, lives with her husband and two grown children. They own a rice grinder which they use to earn a daily income. She will use the loan to increase her sales of rice flour, and also to invest in raising pigs and chickens. Mrs. Lệ is industrious, hardworking, resourceful, and energetic. She will have many sources of revenue to repay the loan (farming, raising animals, and grinding rice). She is the leader of the group of borrowers which includes: Ngô Thị Hào, born 1966. She requests the amount of 4,142,000 VND (245 USD) to raise pigs. Her family's average income is about 2,500,000 VND (149 USD) per month. Phạm Thị Nghi, born 1972. She requests the amount of 4,142,000 VND (245 USD) to invest in a motorbike repair shop. Her family's average income is about 4,000,000 VND (238 USD) per month. Nguyễn Thị Đào, born 1979. She requests the amount of 3,270,000 VND (195 USD) to raise chickens. Her family's average income is about 3,000,000 VND (178 USD) per month. Đặng Thị Lự, born 1971. She requests the amount of 4,142,000 VND (245 USD) to invest in raising livestock. Her family's average income is about 2,500,000 VND (149 USD) per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs and chickens. Motorbike repair shop. Grinding rice.

loans.name: Thi Minh's Group

texts.vi:
Đặng Thị Minh sinh năm 1956 ( mã số 010105060001 ). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng. Gia đình chị có máy làm đậu. Hàng ngày chị thường dậy sớm để làm đậu. Sáng ra chị đem đậu đi chợ bán và cung cấp cho một số cửa hàng ăn uống. Con trai chị cũng đã đi làm hỗ chợ kinh tế gia đình. Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn gồm có:
 Đặng Thị Hoa sinh năm 1964 ( mã số 010105060002). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi gà. Chị có lương hưu hang tháng. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị Lạng sinh năm 1956  ( mã số 010105060005). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi gà, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.500.000 vnđ/ tháng.
 Lê Thị Tâm sinh năm 1969 ( Mã số 010105060007) chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng  bán đồ ăn sang( bún, phở,…). Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Lê Thị Tất sinh năm 1971 ( mã số 010105060009). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi gà, bò. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 4.000.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị Tiến sinh năm 1964 ( mã số 010105060011). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ sắt vụn. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ/tháng.
 Nguyễn Thị Hạnh sinh năm 1963 ( mã số 010105060013). chị vay mức 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư mua thức ăn cho cá . Thu nhập bình quân khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ /tháng.
texts.en:
D. Thi Minh, born 1956 (ID 010105060001), requests a loan of VND4,142,000 for working capital. Monthly income of her family is about VND3,000,000. Her family has a tofu-making machine. Everyday she gets up early to make tofu. Then in the morning she sells tofu in the market and distributes tofu to some restaurants. Her son is also working to support the family. She is the leader of the borrowing group including:

D. Thi Hoa, born 1964 (ID 010105060002), requests a loan of VND4,142,000 to raise chickens. She receives pension every month. Average monthly income of her family is about VND3,000,000.

N. Thi Lang, born 1956 (ID 010105060005), requests a loan of VND4,142,000 to raise chickens. Average monthly income of her family is about VND3,500,000.

L. Thi Tam, born 1969 (ID 010105060007), requests a loan of VND4,142,000 to open a shop selling breakfast (vermicelli, noodles,etc.). Average monthly income of her family is about VND3,000,000.

L. Thi Tat, born 1971 (ID 010105060009), requests a loan of VND4,142,000 to raise chickens and cows. Average monthly income of her family is about VND4,000,000.

N. Thi Tien, born 1964 (ID 010105060011), requests a loan of VND4,142,000 to trade steel scraps. Average monthly income of her family is about VND2,500,000.

N. Thi Hanh, born 1963 (ID 010105060013), requests a loan of VND4,142,000 to buy food for fish. Average monthly income of her family is about VND3,000,000.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Food, food services, livestock, trading

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is Victoria Y., a 38-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is married and has four children, who are between the ages of 4 and 16 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant (an orphan).

Victoria has been operating a clothing business since 2004. In particular, she sells different women's clothes to her loyal customer base. She works at her business for 12 hours per day and 6 days per week. As a result, Victoria is able to earn approximately $200 from her business. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to buy more clothes for resale purposes. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Victoria thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional clothes

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is Zainabu Mahube, a 26-year-old, single woman from Mwanza. Zainabu Mahube has been operating a tailoring business since 2004. In particular, her business model is as follows: she purchases various materials (vitambaa, vitenge, and kanga) and later makes them into clothing, though she notes that her clothing is primarily for women. She works at her business 12 hours per day and 6 days per week. As such, Zainabu is able to earn approximately $150 from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to purchase more clothes (e.g., kanga and vitenge). In the future, she plans to open another business. Zainabu thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional clothes (e.g., kanga and vitenge)

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is Shamim M., a 39-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is a widow with four children, who are between the ages of 14 and 20 years old.

Shamim M. has been operating a charcoal sales business since 1998. Notably, many Tanzanians use charcoal for fuel to cook their daily meals; indeed, women cook food in small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal) and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene in order to light the charcoal. Fortunately, there is a high demand for charcoal across the country, so charcoal-selling is quite a lucrative profession. She works at her business 16 hours per day, 7 days per week, though she notes that she receives assistance from one employee. In doing so, Shamim currently earns approximately $440 per month from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to purchase more charcoal for resale purposes. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Shamim thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her. As such, one of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional charcoal

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Martha A. from Mwanza. She is married with four children, between the ages of 11 and 25 years old.

Martha has been running a café business, or mama lishe. A mama lishe (local restaurant or café) in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), and plantains (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

Since 2004, Martha has worked at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by two employees. Martha currently earns about 500 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500 USD in order to buy beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. In the future, she plans to expand her café business. Martha thanks you for her support! About the lending partner: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and payback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces for her cafe.

loans.name: Mosi

texts.en: Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Mosi M. from Mwanza. She is single with three children, between the ages of three and 15 years old. Mosi M. has been running a used clothes business since 2006. Her business is selling second-hand clothes from America and Europe, which are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Tanzania to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets and in the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially among the younger generation because of their low cost and the general appeal of anything modern. She works at the business for eight hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee. Mosi M. currently earns about 300 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500 USD in order to buy more used clothes for resale. In the future, she plans to open another business. Mosi thanks you for her support! One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for resale.

loans.name: Naimati

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Naimati G. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, aged 13 and 20-years-old, respectively. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependants because they are orphans.

Naimati has been running a tailoring business since 1998. Her business is purchasing vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print), and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides) and making them into clothing mainly for women. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee. Naimati currently earns about 300 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500 USD in order to purchase more cloth for making clothing. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Naimati thanks you for her support! loans.use: To purchase more cloth for clothes making.

loans.name: Sophia

Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant who is an orphan. Sophia S. has been running a café business since 2007. Her business is a café, or mama lishe, which is a local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consisting of a rough wooden table and some long wooden benches. The food is all local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), and plantains (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. loans.use: To buy rice, beans, meat and vegetables to stock her cafe.

loans.name: Sifa

texts.en: Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Sifa S. from Mwanza. She is single with two children of the ages of six months and six years. Sifa S. has been running a clothes business since 2002. Her business is to sell different new cloths to her customers. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, seven days per week. Sifa currently earns about 350 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500 USD in order to buy new clothes for resale. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Sifa thanks you for your support! About the field partner:. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely has a passion for cooking food. She usually prepares rice cakes, which she sells to her neighbors. She is married to Rodolfo, a house carpenter. They have two children: Girly is 25 years old, married, and has finished a two-year course and is working; Dionicio is 19 years old, and a first-year high school student. 

Rice-cake making helps her support their family. However, she used her business' revolving capital when an emergency happened in their family. She now requests a loan of $125 (5,000 PHP) to replace the capital. She plans to use this loan to purchase the ingredients to make rice cakes. 

Her daily income will be of great help to provide for the basic necessities for her family and will help develop the business into a much better income-generating source. If Fely receives the loan, she will do her best to make the business grow, and finally pursue her dream of renovating the kitchen in her house, which serves as the workplace for making her rice cakes.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make rice cakes

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda sells vegetables to her neighbors. She is married to Pedro, a farmer who manages their rice and corn farmland. They are blessed with three children: Gilbert, 20 years old and a college graduate; Gerald, 17 years old and a fourth-year high school student; and Grace,11 years old. Like them, the villagers are disciplined and hardworking too.

Gilda requests a loan of $350 (16,000 PHP). She plans to purchase two piglets for their backyard piggery, and purchase supplies for their small farm. Gilda plans to use a larger portion of the loan to buy vegetables, meat, fish, beef, and other groceries that she can sell to her regular customers. These purchases will help bring in more income to her family. Like any other parents, Gilda dreams of good education for her children and a better life for them.

loans.use: Purchase piglets and farm supplies, and buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Bibiana

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is Bibiana R., a 42-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is married and has two children, who are between the ages of 6 and 20 years old.

Bibiana R. has been operating a clothing sales business since 2001. In particular, she sells both women's and men's clothes to her loyal customer base. She works at her business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. As a result, Bibiana is able to earn approximately $200 per month from her business. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to increase her stock of clothes for resale purposes. Bibiana thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To expand her business by increasing her inventory of clothes

loans.name: Mabe

texts.en:
“It hurts me so bad every time I have to say 'No' to my children when they ask me to buy something because I have nothing to give,” says Mabe V., 35-year-old mother from San Roque, Zamboanga City. With her husband's income from driving a family-owned "tricycle", they could hardly meet all their needs. “I still need to look for ways to augment our family income,” she added.

Because she aspires to a good life for her children, she went into retail business. She runs her store alone and tries to help her husband earn a living for their family. She is requesting a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI to purchase additional items to sell in her store.

“I just want to expand my business slowly. With my loan, I have an edge compared to my competitors,” she said. “Now, I have easy access to credit assistance, training, and the insurance coverage CEVI offers,” she added.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell in her store

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer is a responsible mother of three: Angelo, 6 years old, a day care student; Maria Elyssa, 3 years old; and Princess, 1 month old. Jenifer's husband Bernard earns an income by driving a passenger tricycle, which is the common means of transportation in their village at Sta. Filomena, San Mariano, Isabela.

Jenifer, 30 years old, manages a simple village store in their barangay. She raised the initial capital of $200 (10,000 PHP) to start the store by saving income from her poultry business. The income from the store is not enough to support their daily needs and to generate savings. So Jenifer requests a loan of $125 (6,000 PHP) which she plans to use to purchase additional commodities to sell to her customers.

Someday, Jenifer hopes to send all her children to school so they can earn a degree and not be left behind by their peers. Praying accompanied by patience and hard work will give them the best results, she said.

loans.use: Purchase additional commodities to sell in the general store

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings!) from Tanzania! This is Debora B., a 27-year-old, single woman from Mwanza. Debora has been operating a poultry (kuku) sales business since 2006. Raising kuku--chickens in Swahili--is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Further, raising them for sale is a popular business in Tanzania for a number of reasons. First, they require little start-up capital: you can start with just one or two kuku and either add more as your business expands or wait for them to (naturally) multiply! Second, kuku do not need a great deal of space or any special facilities, so you can normally just let them run around your garden or compound. Third, kuku produce eggs while they grow, and the eggs can either be sold so as to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. She works at her business 12 hours per day, 7 days per week, thereby enabling Debora to earn approximately $90 per month from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to expand and improve her chicken-selling business. In the future, she plans to open another poultry business around her home. Debora thanks you for her support!
